awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: HDR DSC: Infusion of Data Science and Computation into Engineering Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a curricular framework for data science education and workforce development that is transferable between diverse institutions, so STEM-related programs can plug and play data science lessons with existing curricula without much overhead. These lessons will be created in conjunction with community stakeholders and industry partners to ensure a focus on real-world problem solving and include student organizations in course development to promote flexible learning pathways. The proposed additions to undergraduate STEM education will provide an evidence-based blueprint for best practices in integrating data science with existing engineering curricula. Implementation across multiple engineering departments will result in a significant impact on society through the training of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce with high data literacy. 

The objectives of this project are to (1) facilitate data science education and workforce development for engineering and related topics, (2) provide opportunities for students to participate in practical experiences where they can learn new skills in a variety of environments, and (3) expand the data science talent pool by enabling the participation of undergraduate students with diverse backgrounds, experiences, skills, and technical maturity in the Data Science Corps. This work will support the Data Science Corps objective of building capacity for education and workforce development to harness the data revolution at local, state, and national levels. The institutions gathered for this project will develop training programs and curate datasets that will be made available so they can be included in undergraduate instruction nationwide. Furthermore, the training materials will be shared with industry partners, facilitating workforce development. The project team will develop a website to house data science training programs, didactic datasets, and other resources for educators. These resources are intended to reduce barrier to entry for faculty seeking to incorporate data science into their instruction, as recruiting and retaining faculty to create and teach integrated introductory courses in data science has been recognized as a significant hurdle by the National Academies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the collaborative research project, HDR DSC: Infusion of Data Science and Computation into Engineering Curricula, was to develop a curricular framework for data science education and workforce development that could be easily transferred between diverse institutions. This framework aimed to enable STEM-related programs to seamlessly integrate data science lessons into existing curricula with minimal effort. At Tennessee State University (TSU), the specific objective was to incorporate lessons from the Introduction to Data Science module into the AREN 4450 Energy Conservation in Buildings course. This initiative also sought to explore how these concepts could be effectively applied within predominantly Black communities.

The integration of data science into the architectural engineering curriculum was successfully achieved through the AREN 4450 Energy Conservation in Buildings course. Students participated in activities such as conducting field measurements to collect real-world data, receiving training in data science fundamentals like data cleaning, preprocessing, and regression modeling, and applying these techniques to analyze the collected data. These efforts culminated in student-led research projects. Thirteen undergraduate civil and architectural engineering students gained practical experience in tackling real-world engineering challenges using data science tools and methodologies. Surveys conducted as part of the project provided valuable insights into the project’s effectiveness and impact.

This initiative demonstrated the applicability of data science principles to engineering challenges. The hands-on activities, data analysis, and research projects provided a deeper understanding of effective pedagogical methods for teaching data science in an engineering context. As an HBCU, TSU serves a diverse student population, with more than 70% comprising minorities, women, veterans, and non-traditional students. This project broadened participation in STEM fields by actively engaging underrepresented minorities and advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion in engineering and data science education.

The outcomes of this project underscore the transformative potential of interdisciplinary teaching. By enriching educational experiences, fostering collaboration, and addressing complex challenges, it highlights how integrating data science into engineering curricula can prepare students for dynamic and data-driven career pathways.


Last Modified: 01/19/2025
Modified by: Zufen Wang
